newsitem.title: UK: Natwest charges 50 mln for options "error".
newsitem.headline: Natwest charges 50 mln for options "error".

text.p: Britain's National Westminster Bank Plc said on Friday it had found mispricing errors in the interest rate options book of its Natwest Markets unit, and the group would be making a provision of 50 million stg.

"A senior trader has been suspended for failure to supervise, pending the conclusion of an internal inquiry," the bank said in a statement, adding it had reported a second trader who has left the firm to the Securities & Futures Authority (SFA) regulator.
Natwest added that no client had been affected by the discovery, and added: "the Bank of England is being kept informed".

Earlier this week, when announcing the bank's 1996 results, Natwest chairman Lord Alexander said the group saw the pace of economic growth slowing and the bank "adopting a more cautious approach to lending".
Natwest Markets, on the other hand, said it believed the slowdown could boost its activities after a very strong 1996 for its treasury, corporate finance and equities divisions.

One highlight of Natwest Markets' results was a surge in profits from what it called "other dealing" to 171 million pounds ($278 million) from 137 million pounds -- mainly the result of strong increases in interest rate risk management products, among them interest rate options. ($1=.6140 Pound)
